In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can solve this problem using the built-in functions `lowercase`, `strip` and `replace`. Here is how:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    # Convert to lower case
    col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Remove leading/trailing whitespaces
    col = strip(col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    col = replace(col, " " => "_")
    col = replace(col, "-" => "_")
    
    return col
end
```
You can now use this function to clean a column name. For example: 

```julia
> clean_column(" My Column ")
"my_column"
```

This function will work for any valid input. It uses the `lowercase` function to convert the string to lower case, the `strip` function to remove any leading or trailing whitespaces, and the `replace` function to replace all spaces and hyphens with underscores.
